As the sun began to set on the bustling city of Jacksonville, a Hare Krishna pedicab driver named Krishna prepared for his shift at the Jaguars football game. Unlike many of the other pedicab drivers, Krishna saw his work not just as a way to make a living, but as a form of service to his deity, Lord Krishna.

As he pedaled his way through the crowded streets, Krishna recited the verses of the Bhagavad-Gita in his mind, drawing strength and inspiration from the ancient Hindu scripture. He remembered the story of the great battle at Kurukshetra, where the warrior Arjuna was faced with the difficult decision of whether to fight his own kin. Lord Krishna, appearing before him in his divine form, counseled Arjuna to fulfill his duty as a warrior and fight, but to do so without attachment to the outcome.

As Krishna navigated through the crowds of football fans, he couldn't help but feel a sense of purpose and duty in his own work. While many of the other pedicab drivers were more interested in cheating and scamming their customers, Krishna saw his role as a chance to serve and uplift others. He offered his rides with a kind smile and a genuine desire to help, even if it meant a lower profit for himself.

As the night went on and the game came to an end, Krishna reflected on the lessons he had learned from the Bhagavad-Gita. He knew that the true purpose of life was not to seek personal gain, but to serve and uplift others. And as he pedaled his way home, feeling exhausted but fulfilled, he knew that he had done his best to follow the path of righteousness and devotion to Lord Krishna.
